pages.text: The $(thing)Pit Burn$() process is comprised of the following steps:$(p)  $(l:adapt/pit_burn#step_1)1. Place$()$(br)  $(l:adapt/pit_burn#step_2)2. Ignite$()$(br)  $(l:adapt/pit_burn#step_3)3. Cover$()$(br)  $(l:adapt/pit_burn#step_4)4. Wait$()$(br)  $(l:adapt/pit_burn#step_5)5. Uncover$()$(p)The following pages serve to illustrate and expound upon the $(thing)Pit Burn$() process.

First, dig a pit in the ground and place your ingredient(s) into it.$(p)$(info) The pit can be larger than illustrated.$(p)$(warning) The $(thing)Pit Burn$() will fail if the pit is too large or is not completely filled with ingredients.

Second, use any $(l:appendix/ignition)verified fire-starting device$() and ignite the exposed ingredient.$(p)Since the $(thing)Pit Burn$() must ultimately be covered with solid, non-flammable material:$(p)$(info) It is advised that before you light the burn, you completely cover all exposed ingredients, with the exception of one ingredient, which you will use to light the burn.

Immediately after lighting the exposed ingredient, cover your burn with a solid, non-flammable material.$(p)$(warning) At this point, the ingredients in the pit must be completely covered on all sides by solid, non-flammable materials or the $(thing)Pit Burn$() will fail.$(p)If done correctly, you will notice the burning ingredients continue to smoke.

After covering your burn, wait for it to complete.$(p)$(info) While the $(thing)Pit Burn$() is active, the burning ingredient will produce smoke, and, when the burn completes, the smoke will stop.$(p)$(warning) During this phase, do not remove any of the material surrounding the burn until the smoke stops. If the $(thing)Pit Burn$() is disturbed, it may be reduced to ash or nothing at all.
Finally, after the smoke has stopped, remove any of the material covering the $(thing)Pit Burn$() and sift through the ash for the results.
